title: AB 575
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The state board is required to adopt basic instructional materials for kindergarten and grades 1 to 8, with a minimum of five materials for each subject area. The state board must adopt at least five basic instructional materials for language arts, including spelling, reading, and English language development, for applicable grade levels. The board may not adopt materials for this subject area in the year following the adoption of materials for the same grade level. The state board must adopt basic instructional materials for various subjects including Mathematics, Science, Social Science, Bilingual or bicultural subjects, and any other subject deemed necessary. Procedures for submission of instructional materials must be established to comply with these requirements. Instructional materials can be submitted for adoption in different subject areas every eight years, with restrictions on resubmission of rejected materials without substantive changes. If revisions to instructional material are submitted for review after the specified timeframe, a fee will be assessed on the publisher or manufacturer. The fee should not exceed the reasonable costs for the department to conduct the review. Instructional materials must be adopted or rejected within six months of submission, with a possible extension of up to three months if needed. The review process for instructional materials involves committees with volunteer experts and teachers from various grade levels and subjects. Rules for adoption must be transparent and consistent for all formats of materials. The rules for adoption of instructional materials must be transparent and consistently applicable for all formats, including print, digital, and open-source materials. The state board must use specific criteria to ensure that submitted materials meet certain standards. The state board must use specific criteria to review and adopt basic instructional materials, ensuring they align with the state's curriculum framework and meet specified requirements and guidelines for social content. Basic instructional materials must comply with specific requirements, be factually accurate, reflect current research, and align with state content standards. Instructional materials must be factually accurate, reflect current research, align with state content standards, and avoid unnecessary exposure to commercial branding. Commercial branding may only be used with state board approval based on specific findings. When using instructional materials, commercial branding can be included if necessary for educational purposes or if incidental to an illustration. Approval from the state board is required for the use of commercial branding in instructional materials. Commercial branding can be included in instructional materials if necessary for educational purposes or incidental to an illustration, with approval from the state board required. Other criteria may also be established by the state board to meet the intent of relevant laws. The state board may reject basic instructional materials and provide a written explanation based on established criteria. They can adopt fewer than five materials if less are submitted. If fewer than five basic instructional materials meet the criteria or fail to meet the state board's curriculum framework, the state board may reject them. If fewer than five materials are adopted, a review will be conducted to ensure consistency with the curriculum framework. The state board has the authority to adopt materials that are not basic instructional materials. The state board shall prescribe procedures for an open and flexible materials submission system to ensure that adopted materials meet the educational needs of diverse pupil populations, represent cultural pluralism, and provide a broad spectrum of knowledge and technology-based materials. The state board adopts instructional materials and provides a listing with unit costs for publishers and schools. The materials remain on the list until a new curriculum framework is adopted. The state board adopts instructional materials based on a new curriculum framework and provides a list with unit costs for publishers and schools. The lists of adopted instructional materials are available by subject and grade level to school districts and on the department's website, including information about the publisher and any necessary corporate logos. The state board may adopt regulations for exceptions to this section, as determined by the board. The Superintendent will develop guidelines for implementation. Section 60227 defines followup adoptions within an eight-year cycle. Section 60227 of the Education Code defines followup adoptions as any adoption other than the primary adoption within an eight-year cycle. The department must post a notice on their website and notify publishers before conducting a followup adoption in a subject area. Before conducting a followup adoption, the department must post a notice on their website and notify publishers. Publishers participating will be assessed a fee based on the number of programs and grade levels submitted for review. The department will charge a fee for follow-up adoptions to cover costs, keeping it reasonable by avoiding duplication of work from the primary adoption process. The department charges a fee for follow-up adoptions to cover costs, requiring publishers or manufacturers to declare intent to submit specific programs for the adoption. The fee is payable even if a program is withdrawn or grade levels reduced. The department assesses a fee for program coverage, payable by the publisher or manufacturer even if the program is withdrawn or grade levels reduced. A submission will not be reviewed for adoption until the fee is paid in full. The Legislature intends for the fee for participation in follow-up adoptions to not be prohibitive for small publishers or manufacturers. The state board may reduce the fee upon request for small publishers or manufacturers meeting specific criteria. The revenue from fees for follow-up adoptions will be budgeted for reimbursements and can cover adoption and instructional material review costs. If there is little interest from publishers, the follow-up adoption may not be conducted. General fund revenue cannot be used for follow-up adoption costs. The section specifies that general fund revenue cannot be used for follow-up adoption costs. It will be in effect until January 1, 2024, unless a later statute extends or deletes that date.
